components.label: formEnv
HTML
components.content:
Animals and pests

Animals and pests can:

  • contaminate surfaces, equipment and food
  • transfer bacteria from their bodies onto anything they touch.

Guide dogs and other assistance animals are allowed in any area used by customers. Assistance animals are defined by the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (Cth).

Only dogs are allowed in outdoor dining areas if you as the business choose to allow them. Check with your local council for the rules that apply in your area.

Before you start

To complete this topic you will need to think about how you:

  • prevent pests
  • manage animals at your food business

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Animals and pests

components.legend: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
Ways to stop pests may include:
  • flyscreens on windows and doors
  • seal any holes, cracks or gaps in ceilings, walls, floors or around pipes etc.
  • remove waste regularly
  • keep your food business clean, inside and outside.

components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
Well done.

Regular inspection and maintenance of your premises helps to stop pests entering your food business.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated from pests. Pests must be stopped from entering your premises. Keeping a clean business will also help to discourage pests.

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Do you have regular pest control done to remove     pests?
components.label: Do you have regular pest control done to remove     pests?
Do you have regular pest control done to remove pests?.
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Remember to check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs) between treatments. Call your technician if you need extra treatment.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated.

Consider these actions:

  • Have regular pest control done and keep receipts for each time it is done.
  • Regularly check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs).

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Do animals enter food handling areas?
components.label: Do animals enter food handling areas?
HTML
components.content: For example, dogs, birds or other animals in the kitchen, storerooms and the loading dock.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

They may contaminate food and surfaces.

The only live animals that you can have include:

  • fish in decorative tanks
  • live seafood for sale.

If you keep live animals, you will need to have food safety processes in place to keep and handle the live animals. For example:

  • protect food handling areas when you clean fish tanks
  • clean tanks using equipment that is not used to prepare food
  • practice good hand hygiene after handling the animals.

Further information can be found on the web page listed at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Well done

Animals (other than live seafood for sale, or decorative fish tanks) are not allowed in areas where you handle food.

components.legend: Do you allow animals in outdoor dining areas?
components.label: Do you allow animals in outdoor dining areas?
HTML
components.content: Select no if you do not have an outdoor dining area.

components.label: Do you allow animals in outdoor dining areas?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Only dogs are allowed in outdoor dining areas.

Remember:

  • It is your choice to allow dogs into your outdoor areas.
  • You are responsible for making sure they do not contaminate any part of your premises.
  • You must allow assistance animals in all customer areas. Assistance animals are registered animals (e.g.: guide dogs) and do not include pets or companion animals.

To find out more about the responsibilities you and your customers must follow when allowing dogs in outdoor dining areas, see the webpage content provided at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Did you know?

You can choose to allow dogs in outdoor dining areas.

Remember, assistance animals are allowed in all customer areas. Assistance animals are registered animals (e.g.: guide dogs) and do not include pets or companion animals.

Further information about the responsibilities you and your customers must follow can be found at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Animals and pests self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:

  • View resources for more information about this topic
  • Download a summary of your self-assessment
  • Email a summary of your self-assessment
  • Start another next self-assessment topic

Contact your local council if you would like further information or resources for your food business.

Resources

Download guideline (PDF, 40 KB)

Animals in food premises

Information about the legislative requirements for animals in food business including definitions, tips for maintaining food safety standards and customer responsibilities.

Go to website

components.label: formEnv
HTML
components.content:
Health and hygiene

Food safety is the responsibility of both the owner of a business and all staff employed at the business.

As a food business, you are responsible for making sure that staff are provided with a way to wash their hands. Handwashing is an easy way to prevent cross contamination.

Food handlers who are sick can infect surfaces and customers’ food. It is the responsibility of both the food business and food handlers to not handle or deliver food when unwell.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • Have employees been told about their health and hygiene duties?
  • Do you make sure that sick employees do not handle or go near food?
  • Have staff been told about when and how often to wash their hands?
  • Can staff access hand washing basins at all times?
  • Does your hand wash basin have warm running water, soap, paper towels and a bin (or air dryer)?

components.label: HTML
components.content:

  • Terms and Conditions
  • Privacy statement

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Health and hygiene

components.legend: Does each hand wash basin have:
components.label: Does each hand wash basin have:
HTML
components.content:
• warm running water
  • soap
  • single use towel or other method to dry hands
  • bin for used towels

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Well done

To help remind staff, posters are available at the end of the topic in the food safety resource kits.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is very important to prevent contamination in your food business.

You must have warm running water, soap, single use towels (or air dryer) and a bin at your hand washing basin. It is better to use liquid soap as bar soap and soap dishes can become contaminated.

Hand gels and sanitisers should not be used instead of soap and water.

Resources on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.legend: Do staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
components.label: Do staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
HTML
components.content:
For example, to:
  • rinse dishes
  • rinse fruit and vegetables
  • fill up a mop bucket

components.label: Do staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand wash basins must only be used to wash hands, arms and face. Hand wash basins may become contaminated if you use the hand wash basin for other kitchen tasks.

It needs to be clear to staff that the basins are only for washing hands. This can be done by putting up signs or pictures showing hand washing.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do staff know how and when to:
components.label: Do staff know how and when to:
HTML
components.content:
• wash hands
  • change gloves

components.label: Do staff know how and when to:
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Hand washing plays a very important role to stop food poisoning. Gloves must be changed between tasks where you would normally wash your hands.

To help remind staff, posters are available in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is very important to stop food poisoning. Food handlers must wash their hands:

  • when their hands may be contaminated (e.g.: after handling raw meat, after taking out the rubbish)
  • before handling food
  • after using the toilet, smoking, coughing, sneezing, eating, drinking or touching their face or head.

Gloves must be changed between tasks where you would normally wash your hands.

Resources on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.legend: Do staff cover open wounds and sores?
components.label: Do staff cover open wounds and sores?
Do staff cover open wounds and sores?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Weeping from a wound can contaminate food and surfaces. All wounds or sores on an exposed part of the body must be covered with a waterproof covering such as a band-aid or bandage.

Brightly coloured dressings are recommended so they can be easily seen if they fall off.

components.legend: Do staff ensure that nothing from their body or clothing contaminates food?
components.label: Do staff ensure that nothing from their body or clothing contaminates food?
HTML
components.content: For example, nails, jewellery, clothing, hair, bandages, saliva, mucus or blood.

components.label: Do staff ensure that nothing from their body or clothing contaminates food?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Staff must not let anything from their body or clothing contaminate food or surfaces. This may cause harm to your customers.

The fact sheets at the end of the topic provide more information that you can share with your staff.

Alternatively, ask staff to complete the free online training DoFoodSafely which covers health and hygiene.

components.legend: Do you allow anyone to eat or smoke in the food handling areas?
components.label: Do you allow anyone to eat or smoke in the food handling areas?
Do you allow anyone to eat or smoke in the food handling areas?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Smoking and eating in food handling areas can contaminate food and equipment. This may cause harm to your customers and other staff.

The food business must make sure that people (who enter the premise) are not contaminating food, equipment or surfaces. This includes staff, tradespersons, visitors and customers.

You may wish to introduce a visitor log to identify who, when and why a person was in your premises. A sample template is included in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do staff know not to cough, sneeze or spit on equipment,      surfaces or over food?
components.label: Do staff know not to cough, sneeze or spit on equipment,      surfaces or over food?
Do staff know not to cough, sneeze or spit on equipment, surfaces or over food?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Germs are spread by coughing, sneezing and spitting. By making sure staff know these requirements you reduce your risk of making a customer sick.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Germs are spread by coughing, sneezing and spitting. This may cause harm to your customers and other staff.

You need to let staff know the risks and legal requirements. You can give staff fact sheets at the end of the topic or you may choose to get them to complete the free online training program DoFoodSafely.

We recommend you keep a list of the training that you give to staff. A template log is included in the resources to help you.

components.legend: Are staff aware of their health and hygiene responsibilities, including when they are sick?
components.label: Are staff aware of their health and hygiene responsibilities, including when they are sick?
Are staff aware of their health and hygiene responsibilities, including when they are sick?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Staff can accidently contaminate food if they work when they are sick. This may cause harm to your customers and other staff.

The food business must tell all staff about their duties for:

  • good personal hygiene
  • illness
  • hand washing and
  • notifying their supervisor if they have, or think they have, contaminated food.

If the staff are from non-English-speaking backgrounds, the information should be provided in the relevant languages (if possible).

The free online training DoFoodSafely can help staff understand their duties and responsibilities. It is also available in other languages.

We recommend you keep a record of training provided. Template logs are available in the resources list to assist you.

components.legend: Do you have a staff illness procedure or policy?
components.label: Do you have a staff illness procedure or policy?
HTML
components.content:
For example: A procedure or policy that has rules such as:
  • when staff should not work
  • when they can start work again
  • how long should they stay away

components.label: Do you have a staff illness procedure or policy?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

By having a staff illness policy or procedure in place you are making sure staff and customers are not harmed by illness.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

A staff illness policy or procedure helps you to:

  • Manage staff when they are sick and when they are safe to work.
  • Reduce the risk of making other staff and customers sick.

We recommend that you:

  • Create a staff illness policy or procedure.
  • Give your policy or procedure to all staff.

If the staff are from non-English-speaking backgrounds, the information should be provided in the relevant languages (if possible).

components.legend: Do you keep a confidential log when staff are sick?
components.label: Do you keep a confidential log when staff are sick?
HTML
components.content: For example: personal diary entry

components.label: Do you keep a confidential log when staff are sick?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Keeping a log of staff illness helps you prove you are not responsible if a customer alleges food poisoning.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Keeping a log of staff illness helps you prove you are not responsible if a customer alleges food poisoning.

To help you improve food safety, a template register is provided in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you ensure any personal or medical information provided by a food handler     is kept confidential?
components.label: Field Set
HTML
components.content: For example: not tell anyone (such as other staff or customers) except those allowed by legislation.

components.label: Do you ensure any personal or medical information provided by a food handler is kept confidential?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Maintaining confidentiality encourages food handlers to report their illness quickly and assures them that the information will not be used for any purpose other than to protect food from contamination.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Giving out confidential information to anyone other than those permitted in the legislation is against the law.

Maintaining confidentiality encourages food handlers to report their illness quickly and assures them that the information will not be used for any purpose other than to protect food from contamination.

components.label: formEnv
HTML
components.content:
Clean and sanitise

One of most effective ways for making sure your food stays safe is to keep a clean premise. This will help to prevent contamination in the food you prepare and sell.

You need a cleaning system for every area of your business. This includes your premise, equipment and vehicles used to transport food.

Staff responsible for cleaning and sanitising should understand:

  • how to use different chemicals
  • where to clean
  • how to take apart equipment such as food processors to clean and sanitise them correctly.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • Do you have a cleaning roster?
  • Is every area of your food business included in your cleaning roster?
  • Do you or your staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
  • Do you have the right chemicals to sanitise correctly?

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using the Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool

  • Terms and Conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

The Queensland Government respects your right to privacy in using Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool. Any information you give will be handled by the Queensland Government in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

For information about how the Queensland Government protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see out website at www.health.qld.gov.au/legal/privacy

Please note that our terms of use may change over time. Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Clean and sanitise

components.legend: Is your premise kept clean at all times?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • no visible dirt, grease and other matter
  • no build-up of garbage or recycling
  • crumbs and other food waste are not caught in corners or under benches
  • grease filters are cleaned regularly
  • no mould
  • no spider webs

components.label: Is your premise kept clean at all times?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Keeping your premise and equipment clean and sanitised is an easy way to make sure your food is safe.

You may find it helpful to develop a cleaning schedule. A draft procedure including example records is provided at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • benches, shelves, cupboards
  • sinks, handwash basins
  • fridges, cool rooms, bain marie units
  • parts of vehicles used to transport food. Note: vehicles includes shopping trolleys and baskets

components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must clean and sanitise all equipment to prevent food contamination.

You may find it helpful to develop a cleaning roster. You can download a draft procedure, including example records at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • utensils
  • chopping boards
  • work benches
  • equipment

components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces:

  • before you start processing food
  • in between different jobs.

It is also important to regularly clean and sanitise throughout the day, even if used for the same food. This will help to stop germs multiplying during the day.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
components.label: Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must to clean and sanitise eating and drinking utensils after every customer use.

Customers may re-use their own utensils (e.g.: at a buffet). However, when a customer returns the utensils to you, you must clean and sanitise the utensils before they can be used again.

components.legend: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"> Cleaning removes dirt. Sanitising kills germs. They are usually separate steps and must done with food grade chemicals.
</small>

components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cleaning and sanitising play a very important role in making sure you produce safe food. Sanitising can be done two ways, with heat or by using a food grade sanitiser.

There are 6 easy steps to clean and sanitise dishes that are hand washed

  1. Pre-clean: scrape or wipe away food scraps and other matter and rinse with water.
  2. Wash use hot water and detergent to take off any grease and dirt. Soak if needed.
  3. Rinse: rinse off detergent and any loosened residue.
  4. Sanitise: use a sanitiser to destroy any remaining bacteria.
  5. Final Rinse: wash off sanitiser if necessary (refer to manufacturer’s instructions).
  6. Dry: allow to drip dry or dry using single use towels.

Dishes can be sanitised using a commercial dishwasher where the temperature reaches greater than 80 degrees.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you have a cleaning system?
components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
HTML
components.content:
A cleaning system may include:
  • what needs to be cleaned
  • how often cleaning is to be done
  • how something is to be cleaned
  • a roster of who will do the cleaning
  • a record of when cleaning is done
  • details on what chemicals are used.

components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You can prevent food contamination by keeping your premise and equipment clean.

We recommend that you have a cleaning system in place with:

  • processes to describe what needs to be cleaned, how often it is cleaned, and how it is cleaned
  • a cleaning roster for staff
  • a record of when cleaning is done
  • details on what chemicals are required.

For more information, see the cleaning and sanitising guide with an example cleaning record at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Clean and sanitise self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:

  • View resources for more information about this topic
  • Download a summary of your self-assessment
  • Email a summary of your self-assessment
  • Start another next self-assessment topic

Contact your local council if you would like further information or resources for your food business.

components.label: AP Blurb
components.content:
Transport food

You must transport food in a way to keep the food safe. Transport includes moving food from one place to another:

  • within the same premises (e.g. between wards in an aged card facility)
  • to another premises (e.g.: from your kitchen to a market stall or customer’s home)

You will need to plan how and when you transport your food, so that food is not contaminated during delivery. Your plan will need to consider:

  • delivery and dispatch times
  • the vehicle used to deliver the food
  • access to premises
  • a suitable place for the food to be loaded and unloaded.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you protect your food from contamination during transport?
For example, the food is:

  • covered or packaged separately
  • packed to prevent damage
  • kept away from items such as chemicals, pet food or fuel.

components.label: Do you protect your food from contamination during transport?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may be contaminated during transport.

At the end of the topic, there are links to resources and training about how prevent the food contamination during transport. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Are transport vehicles clean and in a good state of repair?

Note: Transport vehicles include shopping trolleys and shopping baskets.

components.label: Are transport vehicles clean and in a good state of repair?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

All transport vehicles must be clean and working properly. For example, if a vehicle is used to transport chilled food, the refrigeration unit must be working.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Is frozen food kept frozen solid during transport?

components.label: Is frozen food kept frozen solid during transport?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

If stated by the manufacturer, frozen food must remain frozen solid at all times including during transport. If the food starts to thaw, it can still be used as chilled food but must not be refrozen.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you transport potentially hazardous food in temperature danger zone?

The temperature danger zone is between 5°C and 60°C.

components.label: Do you transport potentially hazardous food in temperature danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You should limit the time that you keep food in the temperature danger zone. This will help to stop bacteria and toxins from growing in your food.

If food is being transported long distances, or on hot days, we recommend that you use a refrigerated vehicle to keep food cold. For short distances, insulated containers may be enough to keep the food hot or cold.

You must be able to show that you transport food safely, including limiting the time that food is in the temperature danger zone.

The 2-hour/4-hour rule helps you to show that your food is safe. See the fact sheet and template record at the end of this topic for more information on the 2-hour/4-hour rule.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Do Food Safely

Free online training program

Go to website

Transporting food

Information and advice about how to protect food from contamination during transport.

Go to website

2 hour/4 hour rule

A guide to help food business prevent food on display from becoming contaminated by using the 2-hour/4-hour rule for temperature control.

Download factsheet (PDF, 155 KB)

2-hour/4-hour record

A record sheet to demonstrate compliance with the 2 hour/4 hour rule

Download template (DOC, 465 KB)

Temperature danger zone

A poster to display at your food business to remind food handlers about safe temperatures for food.

Download poster (PDF, 61.5 KB)

components.label: AP Blurb
components.content:
Animals and pests

Animals and pests can:

  • contaminate surfaces, equipment and food
  • transfer bacteria from their bodies onto anything they touch.

Guide dogs and other assistance animals are allowed in any area used by customers. Assistance animals are defined by the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (Cth).

Only dogs are allowed in outdoor dining areas if you as the business choose to allow them. Check with your local council for the rules that apply in your area.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
Ways to stop pests may include:

  • flyscreens on windows and doors
  • seal any holes, cracks or gaps in ceilings, walls, floors or around pipes etc.
  • remove waste regularly
  • keep your food business clean, inside and outside.

components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Regular inspection and maintenance of your premises helps to stop pests entering your food business.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated from pests. Pests must be stopped from entering your premises. Keeping a clean business will also help to discourage pests.

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do you have regular pest control done to remove pests?

components.label: Do you have regular pest control done to remove pests?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Remember to check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs) between treatments. Call your technician if you need extra treatment.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated.

Consider these actions:

  • Have regular pest control done and keep receipts for each time it is done.
  • Regularly check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs).

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do animals enter food handling areas?
For example, dogs, birds or other animals in the kitchen, storerooms and the loading dock.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

They may contaminate food and surfaces.

The only live animals that you can have include:

  • fish in decorative tanks
  • live seafood for sale.

If you keep live animals, you will need to have food safety processes in place to keep and handle the live animals. For example:

  • protect food handling areas when you clean fish tanks
  • clean tanks using equipment that is not used to prepare food
  • practice good hand hygiene after handling the animals.

Further information can be found on the web page listed at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Well done

Animals (other than live seafood for sale, or decorative fish tanks) are not allowed in areas where you handle food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you allow animals in outdoor dining areas?
Select no if you do not have an outdoor dining area.

components.label: Do you allow animals in outdoor dining areas?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Only dogs are allowed in outdoor dining areas.

Remember:

  • It is your choice to allow dogs into your outdoor areas.
  • You are responsible for making sure they do not contaminate any part of your premises.
  • You must allow assistance animals in all customer areas. Assistance animals are registered animals (e.g.: guide dogs) and do not include pets or companion animals.

To find out more about the responsibilities you and your customers must follow when allowing dogs in outdoor dining areas, see the webpage content provided at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Did you know?

You can choose to allow dogs in outdoor dining areas.

Remember, assistance animals are allowed in all customer areas. Assistance animals are registered animals (e.g.: guide dogs) and do not include pets or companion animals.

Further information about the responsibilities you and your customers must follow can be found at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Controlling pests

Key information on controlling pests in a food business and practical tips to reduce food safety risks.

Download factsheet (PDF, 121 KB) (https://www.foodstandards.gov.au/foodsafety/standards/Documents/Pests_Final.pdf)

Pest management

Appendix 7 from Safe Food Australia with additional information referred to in the Controlling Pests factsheet.

Download guideline (PDF, 40 KB) (https://www.foodstandards.gov.au/publications/Documents/Safe%20Food%20Australia/Appendix%207%20-%20Pest%20management.pdf)

Animals in food premises

Information about the legislative requirements for animals in food business including definitions, tips for maintaining food safety standards and customer responsibilities.

Go to website (https://www.health.qld.gov.au/public-health/industry-environment/food-safety/requirements/animals)

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Health and hygiene

Food safety is the responsibility of both the owner of a business and all staff employed at the business.

As a food business, you are responsible for making sure that staff are provided with a way to wash their hands. Handwashing is an easy way to prevent cross contamination.

Food handlers who are sick can infect surfaces and customers’ food. It is the responsibility of both the food business and food handlers to not handle or deliver food when unwell.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Does each hand wash basin have:

  • warm running water
  • soap
  • single use towel or other method to dry hands
  • bin for used towels

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Well done

To help remind staff, posters are available at the end of the topic in the food safety resource kits.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is very important to prevent contamination in your food business.

You must have warm running water, soap, single use towels (or air dryer) and a bin at your hand washing basin. It is better to use liquid soap as bar soap and soap dishes can become contaminated.

Hand gels and sanitisers should not be used instead of soap and water.

Resources on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
For example, to:

  • rinse dishes
  • rinse fruit and vegetables
  • fill up a mop bucket

components.label: Do staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand wash basins must only be used to wash hands, arms and face. Hand wash basins may become contaminated if you use the hand wash basin for other kitchen tasks.

It needs to be clear to staff that the basins are only for washing hands. This can be done by putting up signs or pictures showing hand washing.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do staff know how and when to:

  • wash hands
  • change gloves

components.label: Do staff know how and when to:
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Hand washing plays a very important role to stop food poisoning. Gloves must be changed between tasks where you would normally wash your hands.

To help remind staff, posters are available in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is very important to stop food poisoning. Food handlers must wash their hands:

  • when their hands may be contaminated (e.g.: after handling raw meat, after taking out the rubbish)
  • before handling food
  • after using the toilet, smoking, coughing, sneezing, eating, drinking or touching their face or head.

Gloves must be changed between tasks where you would normally wash your hands.

Resources on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do animals enter food handling areas?

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Weeping from a wound can contaminate food and surfaces. All wounds or sores on an exposed part of the body must be covered with a waterproof covering such as a band-aid or bandage.

Brightly coloured dressings are recommended so they can be easily seen if they fall off.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do staff ensure that nothing from their body or clothing contaminates food?
For example, nails, jewellery, clothing, hair, bandages, saliva, mucus or blood.

components.label: Do staff ensure that nothing from their body or clothing contaminates food?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Staff must not let anything from their body or clothing contaminate food or surfaces. This may cause harm to your customers.

The fact sheets at the end of the topic provide more information that you can share with your staff.

Alternatively, ask staff to complete the free online training DoFoodSafely which covers health and hygiene.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do you allow anyone to eat or smoke in the food handling areas?

components.label: Do you allow anyone to eat or smoke in the food handling areas?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Smoking and eating in food handling areas can contaminate food and equipment. This may cause harm to your customers and other staff.

The food business must make sure that people (who enter the premise) are not contaminating food, equipment or surfaces. This includes staff, tradespersons, visitors and customers.

You may wish to introduce a visitor log to identify who, when and why a person was in your premises. A sample template is included in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do staff know not to cough, sneeze or spit on equipment,surfaces or over food?

components.label: Do staff know not to cough, sneeze or spit on equipment, surfaces or over food?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Germs are spread by coughing, sneezing and spitting. By making sure staff know these requirements you reduce your risk of making a customer sick.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Germs are spread by coughing, sneezing and spitting. This may cause harm to your customers and other staff.

You need to let staff know the risks and legal requirements. You can give staff fact sheets at the end of the topic or you may choose to get them to complete the free online training program DoFoodSafely.

We recommend you keep a list of the training that you give to staff. A template log is included in the resources to help you.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Are staff aware of their health and hygiene responsibilities, including when they are sick?

components.label: Are staff aware of their health and hygiene responsibilities, including when they are sick?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

A staff illness policy or procedure helps you to:

The food business must tell all staff about their duties for:

  • good personal hygiene
  • illness
  • hand washing and
  • notifying their supervisor if they have, or think they have, contaminated food.

If the staff are from non-English-speaking backgrounds, the information should be provided in the relevant languages (if possible).

The free online training DoFoodSafely can help staff understand their duties and responsibilities. It is also available in other languages.

We recommend you keep a record of training provided. Template logs are available in the resources list to assist you.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you have a staff illness procedure or policy?
For example: A procedure or policy that has rules such as:

  • when staff should not work
  • when they can start work again
  • how long should they stay away

components.label: Do you have a staff illness procedure or policy?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

By having a staff illness policy or procedure in place you are making sure staff and customers are not harmed by illness.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

A staff illness policy or procedure helps you to:

  • Manage staff when they are sick and when they are safe to work.
  • Reduce the risk of making other staff and customers sick.

We recommend that you:

  • Create a staff illness policy or procedure.
  • Give your policy or procedure to all staff.

If the staff are from non-English-speaking backgrounds, the information should be provided in the relevant languages (if possible).

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you keep a confidential log when staff are sick?
For example: personal diary entry

components.label: Do you keep a confidential log when staff are sick?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Keeping a log of staff illness helps you prove you are not responsible if a customer alleges food poisoning.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Keeping a log of staff illness helps you prove you are not responsible if a customer alleges food poisoning.

To help you improve food safety, a template register is provided in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you ensure any personal or medical information provided by a food handler is kept confidential?
For example: not tell anyone (such as other staff or customers) except those allowed by legislation.

components.label: Do you ensure any personal or medical information provided by a food handler is kept confidential?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Maintaining confidentiality encourages food handlers to report their illness quickly and assures them that the information will not be used for any purpose other than to protect food from contamination.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Giving out confidential information to anyone other than those permitted in the legislation is against the law.

Maintaining confidentiality encourages food handlers to report their illness quickly and assures them that the information will not be used for any purpose other than to protect food from contamination.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Do Food Safely

Free online food safety training

Go to website (http://dofoodsafely.health.vic.gov.au/index.php/en/)

Food handler exclusion guidelines

A guide for determining suitable exclusion periods for ill food handlers.

Food handler health and hygiene

Key information on the health and hygiene responsibilities of both food handlers and food businesses.

Download factsheet (DOC, 999 KB) (https://www.health.qld.gov.au/__data/assets/word_doc/0035/442988/food-handler-health-hygiene.doc)

Feeling sick poster

Hand Hygiene

Food handler

Staff illness log

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Prepare food

Food processing is any activity you do to prepare the food. This includes thawing, washing, chopping, cooking, drying, fermenting, heating or pasteurising.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you handle food as little as possible?

For example:

  • Only get ingredients out of the fridge when you are going to use them.
  • Not getting distracted during tasks that you then have to re-do.
  • single use towel or other method to dry hands
  • Not having more than one staff member handle the same food item.

components.label: Do you handle food as little as possible?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You increase the risk of food becoming contaminated:

  • the more you touch the food
  • the more people who touch the food.

Think about your processes to see if you can reduce the amount of time or people who handle food.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do food handlers have the right skills and knowledge for each processing activity they do?

components.label: Do food handlers have the right skills and knowledge for each processing activity they do?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Staff who don’t know why activities need to be done a certain way:

  • may contaminate food
  • may cause food poisoning to your customers.

You may wish to share some of the factsheets at the end of the topic with your staff. DoFoodSafely is a free online training website that is available for staff. This training will provide staff with basic food safety knowledge.

We recommend that you keep a log of the food safety training completed by staff. A template record is included in the resources to help you.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Are there any pests (ants, spiders, mice) in processing areas?

components.label: Are there any pests (ants, spiders, mice) in processing areas?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated from pests. Pests must be stopped from entering your premises. Keeping a clean business and preventing pest entry will help to discourage pests.

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content: Are utensils, equipment and surfaces cleaned and sanitised before and between use?

components.label: Are utensils, equipment and surfaces cleaned and sanitised before and between use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Weeping from a wound can contaminate food and surfaces. All wounds or sores on an exposed part of the body must be covered with a waterproof covering such as a band-aid or bandage.

Brightly coloured dressings are recommended so they can be easily seen if they fall off.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do you keep utensils in containers of water?

components.label: Do you keep utensils in containers of water?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Utensils stored in water, especially when not changed regularly, may cause food poisoning bacteria to grow and spread to food.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Are chemicals kept away from food processing areas?

For example:

  • insect sprays
  • cleaning products

components.label: Are chemicals kept away from food processing areas?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Chemicals can contaminate food. You must keep all chemicals away from food processing areas.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do you mix or top-up batches of food?

components.label: Do you mix or top-up batches of food?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You should not mix or top-up different batches of food. Bacteria or other contaminates can transfer from the leftover food to the new food. This may cause food poisoning to your customers.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do you take steps to prevent cross contamination when making food?

components.label: HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • use separate chopping boards
  • regularly clean and sanitise equipment and utensils
  • have separate utensils for different foods or jobs
  • handle food and money separately
  • not use tea towels for drying hands

components.label: Do you take steps to prevent cross contamination when making food?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Cross contamination is one of the main causes of food poisoning and allergic reactions.

You reduce the risk of harming a customer when:

  • staff have processes to prevent cross contamination of food
  • staff understand why they must follow the processes.

Posters on cross contamination can be found at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cross contamination is one of the main causes of food poisoning and allergic reactions.

We recommend you reduce the risk of harming a customer by:

  • having processes to prevent cross contamination of food
  • training staff in how to do these processes
  • training staff so that they understand why they must follow the processes.

At the end of this topic, you can find:

  • fact sheets and posters on cross contamination
  • a guide on how to develop a cleaning roster with a template to record cleaning.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you limit the time that potentially hazardous food is in the temperate danger zone?

The temperature danger zone is between 5°C and 60°C.

components.label: Do you limit the time that potentially hazardous food is in the temperate danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Bacteria and toxins can grow in food when it is in the temperature danger zone. This is one of the main causes of food poisoning.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You should limit the time that you keep food in the temperature danger zone. This will help to stop bacteria and toxins from growing in your food.

The 2-hour/4-hour rule helps to keep food safe, if you are processing the food in the temperature danger zone.

See the fact sheet at the end of this topic for more information on the 2-hour/4-hour rule.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Can you show food is cooked all the way through?

components.label: Can you show food is cooked all the way through?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food must be cooked all the way through to prevent food poisoning.

Some of the ways to make sure that cook is food correctly include:

  • Have a standard procedure for staff to follow when they cook, so that food so that it is cooked the same way each time.
  • Measure the internal temperature of the food each time, to make sure it is above 60°C.
  • Juices run clear from meat.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
When cooling potentially hazardous food, do you make sure the food is:

  • cooled from 60°C to 21°C within two hours
  • cooled from 21°C to 5°C within an additional four hours

components.label: When cooling potentially hazardous food, do you make sure the food is:
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may be taking too long to cool down. This can allow food poisoning bacteria or toxins to grow in your food.

You can reduce the time it takes to for food to cool by:

  • cooking smaller portions
  • separating batches into smaller, shallow containers.

See the factsheet below for more information on cooling food safety. To show you are cooling food safely, you can choose to keep records like the template record sheet at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
When reheating potentially hazardous food, do you make sure food is

  • reheated to 60°C or hotter within 2 hours

components.label: When reheating potentially hazardous food, do you make sure food is
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your reheated food may not be safe as it has taken too long to reach a temperature that stops the growth of food poisoning bacteria or toxins.

See the factsheet at the end of the topic for more information on reheating food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you thaw or defrost frozen food safely?

Safe methods include:

  • place the frozen food in the refrigerator
  • place under cold running water
  • defrost in the microwave
  • heat as part of the cooking process.

components.label: Do you thaw or defrost frozen food safely?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

It is also important to make sure the juices from your thawed food do not drip onto other food contaminating it.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food must be thawed safely to limit the growth of food poisoning bacteria and toxins.

It is important to make sure the juices from the thawing food do not drip onto other food contaminating it.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you use food grade packaging?
Containers or wrapping that is suitable to use with food.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You may be contaminating your food by using materials that are not suitable. Your supplier will be able to advise if the products are ok to use with food if it is not written on the packaging.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you use single use items more than once?

For example:

  • gloves
  • foils, wrappers and packaging
  • ice cream containers and disposable takeaway containers

components.label: Do you use single use items more than once?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Single use items are designed to only be used once. They must be thrown out:

  • after they have been used
  • if they are potentially contaminated.

Single use items cannot be washed or used again.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Skills and knowledge

Everyone working in a food business must have some skills and knowledge to handle food safely.

The level of food safety skills needed, will depend on the tasks done. For example, a chef that prepares food will need to know more about food safety than a shop assistant who restocks the refrigerator.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do you have a food safety supervisor?
All licensed food businesses in Queensland must have a food safety supervisor. Select “No” if you do not need a food business licence.

components.label:
Do you have a food safety supervisor?
All licensed food businesses in Queensland must have a food safety supervisor. Select “No” if you do not need a food business licence.
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

A food safety supervisor is responsible for overseeing the day-to-day management of food safety in your business.

Read the food safety supervisor factsheet at the end of this topic to find out:
  • how to become a food safety supervisor
  • what it means to be a food safety supervisor

components.label: HTML
components.content: Has your food safety supervisor completed training?

components.label: Has your food safety supervisor completed training?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Food safety supervisors need to a high level of food safety knowledge so that they can guide your business.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

While training is not mandatory, we strongly recommend that your food safety supervisor completes training.

Food safety supervisors need to a high level of food safety knowledge so that they can guide your business.

Read the fact sheet at the end of the topic to find out more information about how to get training.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Is food safety training provided to your staff?
For example, dogs, birds or other animals in the kitchen, storerooms and the loading dock.

components.label:
Is food safety training provided to your staff?
For example, dogs, birds or other animals in the kitchen, storerooms and the loading dock.
HTML
components.content:
Well done

We recommend you maintain food safety training records for all food handlers at your food business. This includes:

  • internal training (e.g.: induction training)
  • on the job training
  • external training courses that provide a certificate of completion.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food safety training for staff will reduce the risk of food safety issues. Training could include:

  • induction training for new staff
  • on the job training
  • having staff complete free online courses
  • hiring a consultant to provide specialised training for your business

We recommend you maintain food safety training records for all food handlers at your food business. This includes:

  • internal training (e.g.: induction training)
  • on the job training
  • external training courses that provides a certificate of completion.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do staff know how and when to wash their hands?

components.label: Do staff know how and when to wash their hands?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Hand washing is a very important step in stopping cross contamination.

To help remind staff, hand washing posters are available to download at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is a very important step in stopping cross contamination.

All food handlers must wash their hands:

  • before handling food
  • after using the toilet, smoking, coughing, sneezing, eating, drinking or touching their face or head

Resources including posters on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic and should be shared with your staff.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
Cleaning removes dirt, sanitising kills germs. They are usually separate steps and must done with food grade sanitiser

components.label:
Do staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
Cleaning removes dirt, sanitising kills germs. They are usually separate steps and must done with food grade sanitiser
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cleaning and sanitising play a very important role in making sure you produce safe food. Sanitising can be done two ways, with heat or by using a food grade sanitiser.

There are 6 easy steps to clean and sanitise dishes that are hand washed

  1. Pre-clean: scrape or wipe away food scraps and other matter and rinse with water.
  2. Wash: use hot water and detergent to take off any grease and dirt. Soak if needed.
  3. Rinse: rinse off detergent and any loosened residue.
  4. Sanitise: use a sanitiser to destroy any remaining bacteria.
  5. Final Rinse: wash off sanitiser if necessary (refer to manufacturer’s instructions).
  6. Dry: allow to drip dry or dry using single use towels.

Dishes can be sanitised using a commercial dishwasher where the temperature reaches greater than 80 degrees.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Do staff know how to prevent cross contamination?
Cross contamination is when one item gets contaminated by another object which is already contaminated. For example:

  • touching food with unwashed hands
  • not cleaning and sanitising equipment between uses.

components.label:
Do staff know how to prevent cross contamination?
Cross contamination is when one item gets contaminated by another object which is already contaminated. For example:
  • touching food with unwashed hands
  • not cleaning and sanitising equipment between uses.
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Cross contamination is one of the leading causes of food poisoning.

You can reduce the risk of accidentally poisoning a customer when staff know:
  • how to handle food safely
  • ways to avoid contaminating surfaces
  • appropriate food storage methods

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cross contamination is one of the leading causes of food poisoning.

You can reduce the risk of accidentally poisoning a customer when staff know:

  • how to handle food safely
  • ways to avoid contaminating surfaces
  • appropriate food storage methods

Fact sheets and posters on cross contamination can be found at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Do staff know how to use your thermometer?

components.label: Do staff know how to use your thermometer?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is mandatory to have a thermometer accurate to +/-1°C. This allows staff to make sure your food is at the right temperatures during storage, display, transport and processing.

Like all equipment in your business, staff need to know how to use, clean and sanitise the thermometer correctly.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them is included in the example procedure at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Clean and sanitise

One of most effective ways for making sure your food stays safe is to keep a clean premise. This will help to prevent contamination in the food you prepare and sell.

You need a cleaning system for every area of your business. This includes your premise, equipment and vehicles used to transport food.

Staff responsible for cleaning and sanitising should understand:

  • how to use different chemicals
  • where to clean
  • how to take apart equipment such as food processors to clean and sanitise them correctly.

components.legend: Is your premise kept clean at all times?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • no visible dirt, grease and other matte
  • no build-up of garbage or recycling
  • crumbs and other food waste are not caught in corners or under benches
  • grease filters are cleaned regularly
  • no mould
  • no spider webs

components.label: Is your premise kept clean at all times?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Keeping your premise and equipment clean and sanitised is an easy way to make sure your food is safe.

You may find it helpful to develop a cleaning schedule. A draft procedure including example records is provided at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • benches, shelves, cupboards
  • sinks, handwash basins
  • fridges, cool rooms, bain marie units
  • parts of vehicles used to transport food. Note: vehicles includes shopping trolleys and baskets

components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must clean and sanitise all equipment to prevent food contamination.

You may find it helpful to develop a cleaning roster. You can download a draft procedure, including example records at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • utensils
  • chopping boards
  • work benches
  • equipment

components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces:

  • before you start processing food
  • in between different jobs.

It is also important to regularly clean and sanitise throughout the day, even if used for the same food. This will help to stop germs multiplying during the day.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
components.label: Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must to clean and sanitise eating and drinking utensils after every customer use.

Customers may re-use their own utensils (e.g.: at a buffet). However, when a customer returns the utensils to you, you must clean and sanitise the utensils before they can be used again.

components.legend: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"> Cleaning removes dirt. Sanitising kills germs. They are usually separate steps and must done with food grade chemicals.
</small>

components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cleaning and sanitising play a very important role in making sure you produce safe food. Sanitising can be done two ways, with heat or by using a food grade sanitiser.

There are 6 easy steps to clean and sanitise dishes that are hand washed

  1. Pre-clean: scrape or wipe away food scraps and other matter and rinse with water.
  2. Wash use hot water and detergent to take off any grease and dirt. Soak if needed.
  3. Rinse: rinse off detergent and any loosened residue.
  4. Sanitise: use a sanitiser to destroy any remaining bacteria.
  5. Final Rinse: wash off sanitiser if necessary (refer to manufacturer’s instructions).
  6. Dry: allow to drip dry or dry using single use towels.

Dishes can be sanitised using a commercial dishwasher where the temperature reaches greater than 80 degrees.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you have a cleaning system?
components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
HTML
components.content:
A cleaning system may include:
  • what needs to be cleaned
  • how often cleaning is to be done
  • how something is to be cleaned
  • a roster of who will do the cleaning
  • a record of when cleaning is done
  • details on what chemicals are used.

components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You can prevent food contamination by keeping your premise and equipment clean.

We recommend that you have a cleaning system in place with:

  • processes to describe what needs to be cleaned, how often it is cleaned, and how it is cleaned
  • a cleaning roster for staff
  • a record of when cleaning is done
  • details on what chemicals are required.

For more information, see the cleaning and sanitising guide with an example cleaning record at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Receive Food

Food businesses must only receive food that is safe and suitable. This means that food delivered to your business:

  • is protected from contamination
  • is labelled correctly
  • is at the correct temperature when it arrives.

components.legend: Do you record the name and address of your suppliers?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
Do you record the name and address of your suppliers?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must be able to give the name and address for each supplier to a Council officer.

Knowing your supplier’s details, helps:

  • if there is a food recall
  • if you have a food poisoning complaint.

components.legend: Do you check food on arrival for:
components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content:
• correct temperature (<5°C for chilled foods or frozen hard)
  • no signs of contamination
  • packaging is not broken
  • labelling including if the food is in the use-by or best-before date

components.label: Do you check food on arrival for:
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Checking all these things makes sure you only accept safe food into your business. It also helps to reduce stock loss as you can return or seek a credit from your supplier.

components.legend: Do you have a thermometer?
components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is mandatory to have a thermometer accurate to +/-1°C. This allows staff to make sure your food is at the right temperature.

Accurate thermometers can be purchased from catering or kitchen supply stores.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them in included in example procedure at the end of the topic

components.legend: Do you check eggs to see if they are:
components.label: Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
HTML
components.content:
• clean
  • are not cracked
  • have a code stamped on them

components.label:
• clean
  • are not cracked
  • have a code stamped on them
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your eggs may not be safe. Eggs naturally carry bacteria, which makes them a high-risk food.

You should never use cracked or dirty eggs in the preparation of food.

The code stamped on the egg helps to identify which eggs to dispose of:

  • if there is a food recall
  • if you have a food poisoning complaint.

components.legend: Do you get food label information for the food that you receive?
components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content:
Food label information can include:

  • ingredients
  • allergens
  • country of origin labelling
  • name and address of supplier
  • date marks and lot identification
  • storage instructions

components.label:
Food label information can include:

  • ingredients
  • allergens
  • country of origin labelling
  • name and address of supplier
  • date marks and lot identification
  • storage instructions
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Food labelling information will help you to:

  • Give information to your customers, so they can make informed choices based on their dietary needs (e.g.: for an allergy).
  • Manage your stock to use food within its expiry date.
  • Identify food that is part of a recall.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is important that you get food label information from your supplier for each item of food you use.

You can find label information:

  • on the food package
  • attached to the food package
  • in documentation provided by the supplier.

Food labelling information will help you to:

  • Give information to your customers, so they can make informed choices based on their dietary needs (e.g.: for an allergy).
  • Manage your stock to use food within its expiry date.
  • Identify food that is part of a food recall.

components.legend: Is food checked to be in the use-by or best-before date?
components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
Is food checked to be in the use-by or best-before date?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food that is past its use-by date cannot be sold in Queensland for health and safety reasons. However, food that is past it's best-before date may be sold in Queensland.

It is important to check the date marking for all food received to make sure the food is safe to accept.

components.legend: Do you check that the delivery vehicle is clean?

components.label: Do you check that the delivery vehicle is clean?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

By rejecting food that has been contaminated, you are only receiving food that is safe.

We recommend you record the details of any food that you reject.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You may be receiving food that is not safe! Food that is contaminated or does not meet one of the checks above should be returned to the supplier or destroyed.

components.legend: Do you reject food that may be contaminated or does not pass one of the     checks above?

components.label: HTML
components.content: Food that is contaminated, or has not been protected from contamination, is not safe and should be rejected. The food should either be returned to the supplier or destroyed with the supplier's consent.

components.label: Do you reject food that may be contaminated or does not pass one of the checks above?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You may be receiving food that is not safe! Food that is contaminated or does not meet one of the checks above should be returned to the supplier or destroyed.

components.legend: Do you keep a record of checks or food rejected?

components.label: HTML
components.content: For example: a note on an invoice

components.label: Do you keep a record of checks or food rejected?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is helpful to keep some form of record of when food is not accepted. This helps when investigating food poisoning complaints to show you are only accepting safe food.
