components.label: HTML
components.content:
Store food

When food is not being used, it must be kept so it does not become contaminated.

  • how to use different chemicals
  • where to clean
  • how to take apart equipment such as food processors to clean and sanitise them correctly.

components.legend: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
components.label: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  Your storage areas should look, smell and feel clean.
</small>

components.label: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination. Food can become contaminated from chemicals, bacteria, dust or pests.

components.legend: Are storage areas free from pests?
components.label: Are storage areas free from pests?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination.

We recommend you:

  • Have regular pest control done and keep receipts for each time it is done.
  • Regularly check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs). Call your pest control technician if you need extra treatment.
  • Check for pest entry points (e.g.: holes in walls, gaps under doors).

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is food protected from contamination?
components.label: Is food protected from contamination?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • food is covered or packaged
  • food safe containers are used
  • food and equipment are not stored on the floor or in toilet facilities
  • food is stored away from chemicals

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination.

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
components.label: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • food is stored in freezer or fridge
  • food is stored in air-tight containers
  • food is protected from environmental conditions, such as: humidity, temperature and light. For example, dry foods exposed to humidity may absorb the moisture and become unsuitable.

components.label: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Different food will have different storage conditions. We recommend that you check the storage instructions to see how you can keep your food safe and suitable to use.

You can find storage instructions:

  • on the food package
  • attached to the food package
  • in documentation provided by the supplier.

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is your fridge set to less to 5°C?
components.label: Is your fridge set to less to 5°C?
Is your fridge set to less to 5°C?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Potentially hazardous food must be stored at 5°C or below to limit the growth of food poisoning bacteria or toxins.

Further information about potentially hazardous food, including how to store and handle it, can be found in the factsheet at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
components.label: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  Some examples of high risk foods are: raw egg foods such as aioli, mayonnaise
  or mousse.
</small>

components.label: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

It is important to only keep high risk foods for a short time. Some types of bacteria can grow even when the food is refrigerated.

High risk foods should be thrown out each day. We recommend that you make a fresh batch of high risk food every day.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may be unsafe and may cause food poisoning.

It is important to only keep high risk foods for a short time. Some bacteria can grow even when the food is refrigerated.

We recommend that you:

  • Make a fresh batch of high risk food each day.
  • Throw out high risk foods at the end of each day.
  • Label foods with a date that it was opened or made, so that you can keep track of how long each item has been stored for.
  • Follow the storage instructions from your supplier.

components.legend: Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
components.label: Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Frozen food must stay frozen hard while it is being stored. Food that has thawed can still be used as chilled food, but it should not be refrozen.

You may have a problem with your freezer if your food shows signs of thawing while it is being stored. We recommend that you repair or replace your freezer if it does not maintain the correct temperature to keep food frozen.

components.legend: Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1˚C (either above or below)?
components.label: Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1˚C (either above or below)?
Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1˚C (either above or below)?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

All food businesses must have a thermometer that is accurate to +/-1 ° C. This allows staff to make sure your food is stored at the right temperature.

Accurate thermometers can be purchased from catering or kitchen supply stores.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them is included in the example procedure at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
components.label: Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must store food at the correct temperature to prevent food poisoning.

We recommend that you:

  • Check your fridge and freezer each morning to make sure there wasn’t a power failure during the night.
  • Regularly check the fridge and freezer temperature to make sure that you are storing food safely.

components.legend: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
components.label: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  For example: first in, first out principle
</small>

components.label: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Stock rotation means that you use products with the earliest dates first.

Stock rotation helps reduce stock loss caused: by:

  • food expiring past the use-by date
  • food not being the best quality after the best-before date.

components.legend: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
components.label: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
HTML
components.content:
For example: raw food, like meat and seafood, are stored:
  • on a shelf below the ready-to-eat food
  • in a separate storage area

components.label: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Storing raw and read-to-eat food together can contaminate the ready-to-eat food. This may cause food poisoning. You must separate these foods.

components.legend: Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
components.label: Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must keep food that you are getting rid of separate and clearly marked from other food. This is so that you don’t accidentally sell or use this food.

A separate storage area is not required, but a clearly labelled shelf or container is helpful.

components.legend: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
components.label: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Single use items include:
  • disposable gloves
  • drinking straws
  • plastic cutlery (like knives and forks)
  • disposable takeaway containers, wrappers and packaging

components.label: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must prevent single use items from being contaminated while being stored. This includes single use items that customers can access (e.g.: straws).

Some ways to protect single use items from contamination include:

  • store off the floor
  • store in protective packaging or containers
  • store away from chemicals
  • store away from animals, pests and children
  • store ready to use cups, containers and cutlery upside down.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Do Food Safely – Food delivery storage and display

Free online food safety training

Key information about how to store food to keep it safe from contamination.

Information and advice about temperature requirements for food and how to keep food under temperature control.

Go to website

Information and advice about keeping potentially hazardous food at safe temperatures.

A procedure to calibrate a thermometer

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Display and serve food

When you choose to display food at your business, you need to make sure that the food stays safe at all time. This includes food that is:

  • displayed for self-service
  • on a counter bar
  • inside a refrigerator

How you protect food will depend on the way you display it, and the type of food on display.

components.legend: Is food on display protected from contamination?
components.label: Does each hand wash basin have:
HTML
components.content:
Food is protected from contamination when the food is:
  • covered
  • packaged
  • behind a barrier such as a display cabinet or in a fridge
  • kept away from windows and doors
  • kept away from fans and insect sprays
  • kept out of reach from children

components.label: Is food on display protected from contamination?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your displayed food may not be safe. You must protect your food on display from contamination.

components.legend: Do you regularly check that all packaged food is safe to sell?
components.label: Do you regularly check that all packaged food is safe to sell?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • Food is within its use-by or best-before dates
  • Packaging is intact and has not been damaged

components.label: Do you regularly check that all packaged food is safe to sell?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your displayed food may not be safe or suitable. You should regularly check any packaged food on display or in storage to make sure that it is safe and suitable to sell. Remember you cannot sell food past it’s use-by date.

components.legend: Is raw food displayed separated from ready-to-eat food?
components.label: Is raw food displayed separated from ready-to-eat food?
Is raw food displayed separated from ready-to-eat food?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Raw food can have food poisoning bacteria or toxins. The raw food can contaminate the ready-to-eat food when you display these foods next to, or near each other.

We recommend that you display raw food and ready-to-eat food in separate areas.

components.legend: Do you heat food before you add the food to a bain-marie or pie warmer?
components.label: Do you heat food before you add the food to a bain-marie or pie warmer?
Do you heat food before you add the food to a bain-marie or pie warmer?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may not be safe as these types of equipment are designed to keep food warm, not to heat food.

You should not use the bain-marie or pie warmer to heat or re-heat food.

We recommend that you:

  • Always heat or reheat the food in the microwave, oven or stove top.
  • Place the food in the bain-marie or pie warmer to keep it hot.

See the factsheet below for more information on reheating food.

components.legend: Do you keep hot food on display above 60˚C?
components.label: Do you keep hot food on display above 60˚C?
Do you keep hot food on display above 60˚C?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hot food must be displayed at or above 60˚C to prevent the growth of food poisoning bacteria.

components.legend: Do you keep cold food on display at 5˚C or colder?
components.label: Do you keep cold food on display at 5˚C or colder?
Do you keep cold food on display at 5˚C or colder?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cold food must be displayed at or below 5˚C to prevent the growth of food poisoning bacteria.

components.legend: Do you keep perishable food on display in temperature danger zone?
components.label: Do you keep perishable food on display in temperature danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"> The temperature danger zone is between 5°C and 60°C.
</small>

components.label: Do you keep perishable food on display in temperature danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You should limit the time that you display and keep food in the temperature danger zone. This will help to stop bacteria and toxins from growing in your food.

You must be able to show that you keep food for no more than 4 hours in the temperature danger zone.

The 2-hour/4-hour rule helps you to show that your food is safe. See the fact sheet and template record at the end of this topic for more information on the 2-hour/4-hour rule.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do you top up dishes on display when they get low?
components.label: Do you top up dishes on display when they get low?
Do you top up dishes on display when they get low?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may not be safe to eat. You must protect your food on display from contamination.

When you top up food, you can transfer bacteria or toxins from the old batch of food, into the new batch of food. Display smaller portions and replace with a new batch when low.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Well done

When you top up food, you can transfer bacteria or toxins from the old batch of food, into the new batch of food. Display smaller portions and replace with a new batch when low.

components.legend:
Is your unpackaged self-serve food:
  • supervised
  • have separate utensils?
components.label:
Is your unpackaged self-serve food:
  • supervised
  • have separate utensils?
HTML
components.content:
Examples of self-service displays include:
  • buffets
  • salad bars
  • pick-n-mix nuts or lollies

components.label:
Is your unpackaged self-serve food:
  • supervised
  • have separate utensils?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must supervise self-serve foods so that you can quickly remove contaminated food.

For example, remove food that:

  • a customer has touched.
  • a customer has sneezed or coughed on
  • a customer has taken and put back
  • a customer has cross contaminated one food with another food

The level of supervision will depend on the:

  • type of food displayed
  • the number of customers that have access the food
  • how accessible the food is.

You must provide separate serving utensils for each food item to prevent cross contamination. The handles must not come in contact with the food.

components.legend: Do you re-serve food that has been served to another person?
components.label: Do you top up dishes on display when they get low?
Do you re-serve food that has been served to another person?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food that has been placed in front of a customer incorrectly, may be re-served if the customer has not touched the food, and the error is identified immediately.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do you protect single use items from contamination?
components.label: Do you protect single use items from contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Single use items include:
  • plastic drinking straws
  • plastic cutlery
  • single serve sachets or packets of food such as sugar, salt, pepper or sauce
Some ways to protect single serve items include:
  • keep items away from animals, pests and children
  • only place small quantities on display at a time
  • throw away all items after one use
  • throw away items that have been handled by a customer
  • throw away items that have been dropped on the floor
  • throw away items where the outer protective packaging has been damaged.

components.label: Do you protect single use items from contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food that has been placed in front of a customer incorrectly, may be re-served if the customer has not touched the food, and the error is identified immediately.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Do Food Safely

Free online training program

Go to website

Displaying food

Key information about how to protect food from contamination and keep it at the right temperature

Download factsheet (PDF, 127 KB)

A guide to help food business prevent food on display from becoming contaminated by using the 2-hour/4-hour rule for temperature control.

Download factsheet (PDF, 155 KB)

A record sheet to demonstrate compliance with the 2 hour/4 hour rule

Download template

Temperature danger zone

A poster to display at your food business to remind food handlers about safe temperatures for food.

Download poster (PDF, 61.5 KB

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Complaints and recalls

A customer may make a complaint or report that:

  • food from your food business has made them sick
  • the premises is unclean
  • they saw staff not following hygiene requirements.

It is helpful to have a process in place, so staff know what to do if someone makes a complaint about your business.

Food found to be unsafe can be recalled by the manufacturer. It is important that you and your staff know how to identify and separate food that is not to be used due to a recall.

You must have a food recall system in place if you are a:

  • food manufacturer
  • food importer
  • wholesale food supplier.

The food recall system should describe how you will remove unsafe food from use or sale.

If you export food (send it outside of Australia) and identify a public health and safety issue with your product, you are required to notify the Australian Government Department of Agriculture and Water Resources and follow their requirements for recalling food.

components.legend: Do you have a process in place if a customer alleges food poisoning?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
Do you have a process in place if a customer alleges food poisoning?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You and your staff should be prepared if someone alleges that your business caused food poisoning. Remember, your food may not be at fault. The source of illness can only be determined by a proper investigation supported by laboratory tests.

For further advice, see the factsheet at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do your staff know how to manage food allergies and intolerances in your business?
components.label: Do your staff know how to manage food allergies and intolerances in your business?
Do your staff know how to manage food allergies and intolerances in your business?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food businesses must not supply a consumer with a food that is not what they requested.

We recommend that you:

  • Train your staff about the importance of providing correct information to customers about the ingredients in food.
  • Show staff where they can get further information.

For more information, see the links to free training and resources at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do staff know what to do if someone states food from your business has been intentionally contaminated?
components.label: Do staff know what to do if someone states food from your business has been intentionally contaminated?
Do staff know what to do if someone states food from your business has been intentionally contaminated?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • Needles in strawberries
  • Rat poison at a buffet
  • Extorsion claim is made

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

All food businesses in Queensland, who suspect that food at, or sold from, their premises have been intentionally contaminated must notify Queensland Health on 13HEALTH (13 43 25 84).

To help businesses identify and respond to incidents of suspected intentional contamination, see the protocol at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do staff know what to do if a food or ingredient has been recalled?
components.label: Do staff know what to do if someone states food from your business has been intentionally contaminated?
Do staff know what to do if a food or ingredient has been recalled?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Recalled food is unsafe to use and sell. Information on what to do with the recalled food is in the recall notice.

We recommend you have a process in place to:

  • check for food recalls
  • isolate recalled food before you are able to dispose or return the food.

You must keep the recalled food separate and clearly marked until you can:

  • return the food to the supplier
  • dispose of the food.

A separate storage area is not required but a clearly, labelled shelf or container is helpful.

We recommend that you train staff in your food recall process so that they do not accidentally sell or use any recalled food.

components.legend: Do you wholesale, manufacture or import food?
components.label: Do staff know what to do if a food or ingredient has been recalled?
Do you wholesale, manufacture or import food?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Based on how you sell food, you need to have a written food recall plan. A food recall plan should include all the steps to get unsafe food:

  • removed from sale
  • back from other businesses
  • back from consumers

You will find a link to the food industry recall protocol at the end of the topic to help you develop a plan.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Well done

Based on how you sell food, you do not need a food recall plan.

components.label: HTML
components.content:

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Maintenance

Damaged parts and equipment are difficult to clean and may not work properly. This can cause food to become unsafe.

You should regularly check your premises and equipment to make sure that they are in good working order. This includes any vehicles used to transport food.

Having equipment serviced regularly and professionally cleaned helps to maintain your premises and produce safe food.

components.legend: Is  your premise in a good state of repair and working order?
components.label: Is  your premise in a good state of repair and working order?
HTML
components.content:
For example: signs of poor maintenance include:
  • damage to doors and screens
  • loose or cracked tiles on the floors and walls
  • peeling paint and plaster on walls
  • leaking pipes or broken plumbing
  • damaged electrical outlets, lights or fans
  • holes in the ceiling, walls or doors

components.label: Is your premise in a good state of repair and working order?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food premise must be maintained to:

  • prevent contamination of food
  • prevent pests from coming into your food premise
  • clean and sanitise surfaces and equipment correctly
  • have a safe environment for staff and customers.

To improve food safety, consider the following actions:
  • Inspect your food premise to see what you need to repair or replace.
  • Use signage and inform staff of any items that are unsafe to use or could cause food safety issues.
  • Plan service or maintenance activities at a time that will not interfere with food preparation.
  • Create a maintenance schedule and checklist to regularly inspect your premise.

components.legend: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment in a good state of repair and working order?
components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment in a good state of repair and working order?
HTML
components.content:
For example: signs of poor maintenance include:
  • damaged benches, shelves, cupboards
  • broken taps in sinks and handwash basins
  • damaged or broken fridges or cool rooms and their seals
  • damaged ovens, microwaves, grills, fryers, rotisseries, bain-marie units etc
  • broken cooking utensils, food processing equipment or food containers
  • damaged knives, chopping boards, tongs, serving utensils
  • broken shopping trolleys or baskets
  • damaged parts of vehicles used to transport food

components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment in a good state of repair and working order?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Maintaining fittings, fixtures and equipment helps to:

  • prevent contamination of food
  • clean and sanitise surfaces and equipment correctly
  • have a safe environment for staff and customers.

components.legend: Do you have any chipped, cracked or broken plates and cups?
components.label: Do you have any chipped, cracked or broken plates and cups?
Do you have any chipped, cracked or broken plates and cups?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must not use any utensils or equipment that is chipped, cracked or broken. Germs can get into the damaged area. This may contaminate food and make your customers sick.

You should throw out any utensils and equipment that is damaged.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do you regularly have equipment serviced and calibrated?
components.label: Do you regularly have equipment serviced and calibrated?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • fridges and cold rooms
  • dishwashers
  • thermometers
  • exhaust canopies

components.label: Do you regularly have equipment serviced and calibrated?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

To make sure all your equipment is working correctly, it is good practice to have them serviced and calibrated by a specialist.

components.legend: Do you regularly check that your thermometer is working correctly?
components.label: Do you regularly check that your thermometer is working correctly?
HTML
components.content:
You can check that your thermometer is working correctly by:
  • regular calibration
  • replacing the battery
  • fixing or replacing the thermometer if it breaks.

components.label: Do you regularly check that your thermometer is working correctly?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You need an accurate thermometer to get correct temperature readings.

You must regularly calibrate your thermometer to check that it is accurate to +/-1°C.

See the example procedure at the end of the topic to find out how to calibrate a thermometer.

components.legend: Do you have equipment professionally cleaned or serviced when needed?
components.label: Do you have equipment professionally cleaned or serviced when needed?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • exhaust canopies
  • industry deep fryers
  • fridges and freezers
  • grease traps

components.label: Do you have equipment professionally cleaned or serviced when needed?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Specialist equipment should be regularly cleaned and serviced by a professional.

This will help you to:

  • Make sure that the equipment is working correctly to meet food safety requirements
  • Meet other requirements (e.g.: insurance, or where you need to show that your equipment meets Australian Standards).

components.legend: Do you undertake regular pest management?
components.label: Do you undertake regular pest management?
Do you undertake regular pest management?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Remember to check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs) between treatments. Call your technician if you need extra treatment.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated.

Consider these actions:

  • Have regular pest control done and keep receipts for each time it is done.
  • Regularly check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs).
  • Seal any holes or gaps that may allow pest entry.

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Do you have a cleaning system?
components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
HTML
components.content:
A cleaning system may include:

  • what needs to be cleaned
  • how often cleaning is to be done
  • how something is to be cleaned
  • a roster of who will do the cleaning
  • a record of when cleaning is done
  • details on what chemicals are used

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You can prevent food contamination by keeping your premise and equipment clean.

We recommend that you have a cleaning system in place with:

  • processes to describe what needs to be cleaned, how often it is cleaned, and how it is cleaned
  • a cleaning roster for staff
  • a record of when cleaning is done.

For more information, see the cleaning and sanitising guide with an example cleaning record at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Do Food Safely

components.label: formEnv
HTML
components.content:
Skills and knowledge

Everyone working in a food business must have some skills and knowledge to handle food safely.

The level of food safety skills needed, will depend on the tasks done. For example, a chef that prepares food will need to know more about food safety than a shop assistant who restocks the refrigerator.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • the types of food you handle
  • the level of food processing you undertake
  • training of your food safety supervisor and food handlers

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using the Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool

  • Terms and Conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

The Queensland Government respects your right to privacy in using Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool. Any information you give will be handled by the Queensland Government in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

For information about how the Queensland Government protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see out website at www.health.qld.gov.au/legal/privacy

Please note that our terms of use may change over time. Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Skills and knowledge

components.legend: Do you have a food safety supervisor?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> All licensed food businesses in Queensland must have a food safety supervisor. Select “No” if you do not need a food business licence. </small>

components.label: Do you have a food safety supervisor?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

A food safety supervisor is responsible for overseeing the day-to-day management of food safety in your business.

Read the food safety supervisor factsheet at the end of this topic to find out:

  • how to become a food safety supervisor
  • what it means to be a food safety supervisor

components.legend: Has your food safety supervisor completed training?
components.label: Has your food safety supervisor completed training?
Has your food safety supervisor completed training?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Food safety supervisors need to a high level of food safety knowledge so that they can guide your business.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

While training is not mandatory, we strongly recommend that your food safety supervisor completes training.

Food safety supervisors need to a high level of food safety knowledge so that they can guide your business.

Read the fact sheet at the end of the topic to find out more information about how to get training.

components.legend: Is food safety training provided to your staff?
components.label: Is food safety training provided to your staff?
HTML
components.content: For example, dogs, birds or other animals in the kitchen, storerooms and the loading dock.

components.label: Is food safety training provided to your staff?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

We recommend you maintain food safety training records for all food handlers at your food business. This includes:

  • internal training (e.g.: induction training)
  • on the job training
  • external training courses that provide a certificate of completion.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food safety training for staff will reduce the risk of food safety issues. Training could include:

  • induction training for new staff
  • on the job training
  • having staff complete free online courses
  • hiring a consultant to provide specialised training for your business

We recommend you maintain food safety training records for all food handlers at your food business. This includes:

  • internal training (e.g.: induction training)
  • on the job training
  • external training courses that provides a certificate of completion.

components.legend: Do staff know how and when to wash their hands?
components.label: Do staff know how and when to wash their hands?
Do staff know how and when to wash their hands?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Hand washing is a very important step in stopping cross contamination.

To help remind staff, hand washing posters are available to download at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is a very important step in stopping cross contamination.

All food handlers must wash their hands:

  • before handling food
  • after using the toilet, smoking, coughing, sneezing, eating, drinking or touching their face or head

Resources including posters on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic and should be shared with your staff.

components.legend: Do staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
components.label: Do staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
HTML
components.content: Cleaning removes dirt, sanitising kills germs. They are usually separate steps and must done with food grade sanitiser

components.label: Do staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cleaning and sanitising play a very important role in making sure you produce safe food. Sanitising can be done two ways, with heat or by using a food grade sanitiser.

There are 6 easy steps to clean and sanitise dishes that are hand washed

  1. Pre-clean: scrape or wipe away food scraps and other matter and rinse with water.
  2. Wash: use hot water and detergent to take off any grease and dirt. Soak if needed.
  3. Rinse: rinse off detergent and any loosened residue.
  4. Sanitise: use a sanitiser to destroy any remaining bacteria.
  5. Final Rinse: wash off sanitiser if necessary (refer to manufacturer’s instructions).
  6. Dry: allow to drip dry or dry using single use towels.

Dishes can be sanitised using a commercial dishwasher where the temperature reaches greater than 80 degrees.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do staff know how to prevent cross contamination?
components.label: Do staff know how to prevent cross contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Cross contamination is when one item gets contaminated by another object which is already contaminated. For example:
  • touching food with unwashed hands
  • not cleaning and sanitising equipment between uses.

components.label: Do staff know how to prevent cross contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Cross contamination is one of the leading causes of food poisoning.

You can reduce the risk of accidentally poisoning a customer when staff know:
  • how to handle food safely
  • ways to avoid contaminating surfaces
  • appropriate food storage methods

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cross contamination is one of the leading causes of food poisoning.

You can reduce the risk of accidentally poisoning a customer when staff know:

  • how to handle food safely
  • ways to avoid contaminating surfaces
  • appropriate food storage methods

Fact sheets and posters on cross contamination can be found at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do staff know how to use your thermometer?
components.label: Do staff know how to use your thermometer?
Do staff know how to use your thermometer?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is mandatory to have a thermometer accurate to +/-1°C. This allows staff to make sure your food is at the right temperatures during storage, display, transport and processing.

Like all equipment in your business, staff need to know how to use, clean and sanitise the thermometer correctly.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them is included in the example procedure at the end of the topic.

components.label: formEnv
HTML
components.content:
Receive Food

Food businesses must only receive food that is safe and suitable. This means that food delivered to your business:

  • is protected from contamination
  • is labelled correctly
  • is at the correct temperature when it arrives.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • the type of food you receive
  • checks you do when you receive a delivery
  • where is food is delivered and stored until it is checked?
  • what time and day of the week that is food delivered?
  • who are your suppliers?

components.content:

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Receive Food

components.legend: Do you record the name and address of your suppliers?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
Do you record the name and address of your suppliers?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must be able to give the name and address for each supplier to a Council officer.

Knowing your supplier’s details, helps:

  • if there is a food recall
  • if you have a food poisoning complaint.

components.legend: Do you check food on arrival for:
components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content:
• correct temperature (<5°C for chilled foods or frozen hard)
  • no signs of contamination
  • packaging is not broken
  • labelling including if the food is in the use-by or best-before date

components.label: Do you check food on arrival for:
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Checking all these things makes sure you only accept safe food into your business. It also helps to reduce stock loss as you can return or seek a credit from your supplier.

components.legend: Do you have a thermometer?
components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is mandatory to have a thermometer accurate to +/-1°C. This allows staff to make sure your food is at the right temperature.

Accurate thermometers can be purchased from catering or kitchen supply stores.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them in included in example procedure at the end of the topic

components.legend: Do you check eggs to see if they are:
components.label: Do you check eggs to see if they are:
HTML
components.content:
• clean
  • are not cracked
  • have a code stamped on them

components.label:
• clean
  • are not cracked
  • have a code stamped on them
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your eggs may not be safe. Eggs naturally carry bacteria, which makes them a high-risk food.

You should never use cracked or dirty eggs in the preparation of food.

The code stamped on the egg helps to identify which eggs to dispose of:

  • if there is a food recall
  • if you have a food poisoning complaint.

components.legend: Do you get food label information for the food that you receive?
components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content:
Food label information can include:

  • ingredients
  • allergens
  • country of origin labelling
  • name and address of supplier
  • date marks and lot identification
  • storage instructions

components.label: Do you get food label information for the food that you receive?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Food labelling information will help you to:

  • Give information to your customers, so they can make informed choices based on their dietary needs (e.g.: for an allergy).
  • Manage your stock to use food within its expiry date.
  • Identify food that is part of a recall.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is important that you get food label information from your supplier for each item of food you use.

You can find label information:

  • on the food package
  • attached to the food package
  • in documentation provided by the supplier.

Food labelling information will help you to:

  • Give information to your customers, so they can make informed choices based on their dietary needs (e.g.: for an allergy).
  • Manage your stock to use food within its expiry date.
  • Identify food that is part of a food recall.

components.legend: Is food checked to be in the use-by or best-before date?
components.label: Is food checked to be in the use-by or best-before date?
Is food checked to be in the use-by or best-before date?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food that is past its use-by date cannot be sold in Queensland for health and safety reasons. However, food that is past it's best-before date may be sold in Queensland.

It is important to check the date marking for all food received to make sure the food is safe to accept.

components.legend: Do you check that the delivery vehicle is clean?
components.label: Do you check that the delivery vehicle is clean?
Do you check that the delivery vehicle is clean?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

By rejecting food that has been contaminated, you are only receiving food that is safe.

We recommend you record the details of any food that you reject.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You may be receiving food that is not safe! Food that is contaminated or does not meet one of the checks above should be returned to the supplier or destroyed.

components.legend: Do you reject food that may be contaminated or does not pass one of the     checks above?
components.label: Do you reject food that may be contaminated or does not pass one of the     checks above?
HTML
components.content: Food that is contaminated, or has not been protected from contamination, is not safe and should be rejected. The food should either be returned to the supplier or destroyed with the supplier's consent.

components.label: Do you reject food that may be contaminated or does not pass one of the checks above?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You may be receiving food that is not safe! Food that is contaminated or does not meet one of the checks above should be returned to the supplier or destroyed.

components.legend: Do you keep a record of checks or food rejected?
components.label: Do you keep a record of checks or food rejected?
HTML
components.content: For example: a note on an invoice

components.label: Do you keep a record of checks or food rejected?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is helpful to keep some form of record of when food is not accepted. This helps when investigating food poisoning complaints to show you are only accepting safe food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Store food

When food is not being used, it must be kept so it does not become contaminated.

  • how to use different chemicals
  • where to clean
  • how to take apart equipment such as food processors to clean and sanitise them correctly.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • How long you store food for?
  • Is your food protected when it is stored?
  • How do you separate food to be disposed?
  • How do you make sure food for disposal is not used?
  • What single use items do you have in your food business?
  • How do you store the single use items?

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Store food

components.legend: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
components.label: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  Your storage areas should look, smell and feel clean.
</small>

components.label: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination. Food can become contaminated from chemicals, bacteria, dust or pests.

components.legend: Are storage areas free from pests?
components.label: Are storage areas free from pests?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination.

We recommend you:

  • Have regular pest control done and keep receipts for each time it is done.
  • Regularly check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs). Call your pest control technician if you need extra treatment.
  • Check for pest entry points (e.g.: holes in walls, gaps under doors).

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is food protected from contamination?
components.label: Is food protected from contamination?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • food is covered or packaged
  • food safe containers are used
  • food and equipment are not stored on the floor or in toilet facilities
  • food is stored away from chemicals

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination.

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
components.label: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • food is stored in freezer or fridge
  • food is stored in air-tight containers
  • food is protected from environmental conditions, such as: humidity, temperature and light. For example, dry foods exposed to humidity may absorb the moisture and become unsuitable.

components.label: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Different food will have different storage conditions. We recommend that you check the storage instructions to see how you can keep your food safe and suitable to use.

You can find storage instructions:

  • on the food package
  • attached to the food package
  • in documentation provided by the supplier.

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is your fridge set to less to 5°C?
components.label: Is your fridge set to less to 5°C?
Is your fridge set to less to 5°C?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Potentially hazardous food must be stored at 5°C or below to limit the growth of food poisoning bacteria or toxins.

Further information about potentially hazardous food, including how to store and handle it, can be found in the factsheet at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
components.label: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  Some examples of high risk foods are: raw egg foods such as aioli, mayonnaise
  or mousse.
</small>

components.label: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

It is important to only keep high risk foods for a short time. Some types of bacteria can grow even when the food is refrigerated.

High risk foods should be thrown out each day. We recommend that you make a fresh batch of high risk food every day.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may be unsafe and may cause food poisoning.

It is important to only keep high risk foods for a short time. Some bacteria can grow even when the food is refrigerated.

We recommend that you:

  • Make a fresh batch of high risk food each day.
  • Throw out high risk foods at the end of each day.
  • Label foods with a date that it was opened or made, so that you can keep track of how long each item has been stored for.
  • Follow the storage instructions from your supplier.

components.legend: Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
components.label: Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Frozen food must stay frozen hard while it is being stored. Food that has thawed can still be used as chilled food, but it should not be refrozen.

You may have a problem with your freezer if your food shows signs of thawing while it is being stored. We recommend that you repair or replace your freezer if it does not maintain the correct temperature to keep food frozen.

components.legend: Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1˚C (either above or below)?
components.label: Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1˚C (either above or below)?
Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1˚C (either above or below)?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

All food businesses must have a thermometer that is accurate to +/-1 ° C. This allows staff to make sure your food is stored at the right temperature.

Accurate thermometers can be purchased from catering or kitchen supply stores.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them is included in the example procedure at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
components.label: Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must store food at the correct temperature to prevent food poisoning.

We recommend that you:

  • Check your fridge and freezer each morning to make sure there wasn’t a power failure during the night.
  • Regularly check the fridge and freezer temperature to make sure that you are storing food safely.

components.legend: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
components.label: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  For example: first in, first out principle
</small>

components.label: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Stock rotation means that you use products with the earliest dates first.

Stock rotation helps reduce stock loss caused: by:

  • food expiring past the use-by date
  • food not being the best quality after the best-before date.

components.legend: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
components.label: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
HTML
components.content:
For example: raw food, like meat and seafood, are stored:
  • on a shelf below the ready-to-eat food
  • in a separate storage area

components.label: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Storing raw and read-to-eat food together can contaminate the ready-to-eat food. This may cause food poisoning. You must separate these foods.

components.legend: Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
components.label: Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must keep food that you are getting rid of separate and clearly marked from other food. This is so that you don’t accidentally sell or use this food.

A separate storage area is not required, but a clearly labelled shelf or container is helpful.

components.legend: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
components.label: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Single use items include:
  • disposable gloves
  • drinking straws
  • plastic cutlery (like knives and forks)
  • disposable takeaway containers, wrappers and packaging

components.label: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must prevent single use items from being contaminated while being stored. This includes single use items that customers can access (e.g.: straws).

Some ways to protect single use items from contamination include:

  • store off the floor
  • store in protective packaging or containers
  • store away from chemicals
  • store away from animals, pests and children
  • store ready to use cups, containers and cutlery upside down.

components.label: formEnv
HTML
components.content:
Transport food

You must transport food in a way to keep the food safe. Transport includes moving food from one place to another:

  • within the same premises (e.g. between wards in an aged card facility)
  • to another premises (e.g.: from your kitchen to a market stall or customer’s home)

You will need to plan how and when you transport your food, so that food is not contaminated during delivery. Your plan will need to consider:

  • delivery and dispatch times
  • the vehicle used to deliver the food
  • access to premises
  • a suitable place for the food to be loaded and unloaded.

Before you start

To complete this topic you should think about:

  • your delivery and dispatch times
  • the vehicle used to transport the food
  • is the food protected during transport?
  • is food transported under temperature control?

components.label: HTML
components.content:

  • Terms and Conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

For information about how the Queensland Government protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see out website at www.health.qld.gov.au/legal/privacy

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Transport food

components.legend: Do you protect your food from contamination during transport?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
For example, the food is:
  • covered or packaged separately
  • packed to prevent damage
  • kept away from items such as chemicals, pet food or fuel.

components.label: Do you protect your food from contamination during transport?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may be contaminated during transport.

At the end of the topic, there are links to resources and training about how prevent the food contamination during transport. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.legend: Are transport vehicles clean and in a good state of repair?
components.label: Are transport vehicles clean and in a good state of repair?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"> Note: Transport vehicles include shopping trolleys and shopping baskets.
</small>

components.label: Are transport vehicles clean and in a good state of repair?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

All transport vehicles must be clean and working properly. For example, if a vehicle is used to transport chilled food, the refrigeration unit must be working.

components.legend: Is frozen food kept frozen solid during transport?
components.label: Is frozen food kept frozen solid during transport?
Is frozen food kept frozen solid during transport?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

If stated by the manufacturer, frozen food must remain frozen solid at all times including during transport. If the food starts to thaw, it can still be used as chilled food but must not be refrozen.

components.legend: Do you transport potentially hazardous food in temperature danger zone?
components.label: Do you transport potentially hazardous food in temperature danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"> The temperature danger zone is between 5°C and 60°C.
</small>

components.label: Do you transport potentially hazardous food in temperature danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You should limit the time that you keep food in the temperature danger zone. This will help to stop bacteria and toxins from growing in your food.

If food is being transported long distances, or on hot days, we recommend that you use a refrigerated vehicle to keep food cold. For short distances, insulated containers may be enough to keep the food hot or cold.

You must be able to show that you transport food safely, including limiting the time that food is in the temperature danger zone.

The 2-hour/4-hour rule helps you to show that your food is safe. See the fact sheet and template record at the end of this topic for more information on the 2-hour/4-hour rule.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Prepare food

Food processing is any activity you do to prepare the food. This includes thawing, washing, chopping, cooking, drying, fermenting, heating or pasteurising.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • What types of food do you handle?
  • What type of food processing do you do?
  • How you protect food from contamination during processing.

In this section you need to know:

  • Potentially hazardous food is any food that needs to be kept under temperature control to keep it safe.
  • Temperature danger zone is any temperature between 5°C and 60°C.
  • Temperature control if a food is under temperature control it is stored outside of the temperature danger zone at or below 5°C or at or above 60°C.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Prepare food

components.legend: Do you handle food as little as possible?
components.label: Does each hand wash basin have:
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • Only get ingredients out of the fridge when you are going to use them.
  • Not getting distracted during tasks that you then have to re-do.
  • single use towel or other method to dry hands
  • Not having more than one staff member handle the same food item.

components.label: Do you handle food as little as possible?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You increase the risk of food becoming contaminated:

  • the more you touch the food
  • the more people who touch the food.

Think about your processes to see if you can reduce the amount of time or people who handle food.

components.legend: Do food handlers have the right skills and knowledge for each processing activity they do?
components.label: Do food handlers have the right skills and knowledge for each processing activity they do? staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
Do food handlers have the right skills and knowledge for each processing activity they do?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Staff who don’t know why activities need to be done a certain way:

  • may contaminate food
  • may cause food poisoning to your customers.

You may wish to share some of the factsheets at the end of the topic with your staff. DoFoodSafely is a free online training website that is available for staff. This training will provide staff with basic food safety knowledge.

We recommend that you keep a log of the food safety training completed by staff. A template record is included in the resources to help you.

components.legend: Are there any pests (ants, spiders, mice) in processing areas?
components.label: Are there any pests (ants, spiders, mice) in processing areas?
Are there any pests (ants, spiders, mice) in processing areas?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated from pests. Pests must be stopped from entering your premises. Keeping a clean business and preventing pest entry will help to discourage pests.

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Are utensils, equipment and surfaces cleaned and sanitised before and between use?
components.label: Are utensils, equipment and surfaces cleaned and sanitised before and between use?
Are utensils, equipment and surfaces cleaned and sanitised before and between use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cleaning and sanitising must be done:

  • before you start processing food
  • in between different jobs.

It is also important to regularly clean and sanitise throughout the day, even if used for the same food. This will help to stop germs multiplying during the day.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you keep utensils in containers of water?
components.label: Do you keep utensils in containers of water?
Do you keep utensils in containers of water?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Utensils stored in water, especially when not changed regularly, may cause food poisoning bacteria to grow and spread to food.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Are chemicals kept away from food processing areas?
components.label: Are chemicals kept away from food processing areas?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • insect sprays
  • cleaning products

components.label: Are chemicals kept away from food processing areas?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Chemicals can contaminate food. You must keep all chemicals away from food processing areas.

components.legend: Do you mix or top-up batches of food?
components.label: Do you mix or top-up batches of food?
Do you mix or top-up batches of food?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You should not mix or top-up different batches of food. Bacteria or other contaminates can transfer from the leftover food to the new food. This may cause food poisoning to your customers.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do you take steps to prevent cross contamination when making food?
components.label: Do you take steps to prevent cross contamination when making food?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • use separate chopping boards
  • regularly clean and sanitise equipment and utensils
  • have separate utensils for different foods or jobs
  • handle food and money separately
  • not use tea towels for drying hands

components.label: Do you take steps to prevent cross contamination when making food?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Cross contamination is one of the main causes of food poisoning and allergic reactions.

You reduce the risk of harming a customer when:

  • staff have processes to prevent cross contamination of food
  • staff understand why they must follow the processes.

Posters on cross contamination can be found at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cross contamination is one of the main causes of food poisoning and allergic reactions.

We recommend you reduce the risk of harming a customer by:

  • having processes to prevent cross contamination of food
  • training staff in how to do these processes
  • training staff so that they understand why they must follow the processes.

At the end of this topic, you can find:

  • fact sheets and posters on cross contamination
  • a guide on how to develop a cleaning roster with a template to record cleaning.

components.legend: Do you limit the time that potentially hazardous food is in the temperate danger zone?
components.label: Do you limit the time that potentially hazardous food is in the temperate danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  The temperature danger zone is between 5°C and 60°C.
</small>

components.label: Do you limit the time that potentially hazardous food is in the temperate danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Bacteria and toxins can grow in food when it is in the temperature danger zone. This is one of the main causes of food poisoning.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You should limit the time that you keep food in the temperature danger zone. This will help to stop bacteria and toxins from growing in your food.

The 2-hour/4-hour rule helps to keep food safe, if you are processing the food in the temperature danger zone.

See the fact sheet at the end of this topic for more information on the 2-hour/4-hour rule.

components.legend: Can you show food is cooked all the way through?
components.label: Can you show food is cooked all the way through?
Can you show food is cooked all the way through?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food must be cooked all the way through to prevent food poisoning.

Some of the ways to make sure that cook is food correctly include:

  • Have a standard procedure for staff to follow when they cook, so that food so that it is cooked the same way each time.
  • Measure the internal temperature of the food each time, to make sure it is above 60°C.
  • Juices run clear from meat.

components.legend: When cooling potentially hazardous food, do you make sure the food is:
components.label: When cooling potentially hazardous food, do you make sure the food is:
HTML
components.content:
• cooled from 60°C to 21°C within two hours
  • cooled from 21°C to 5°C within an additional four hours

components.label: When cooling potentially hazardous food, do you make sure the food is:
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may be taking too long to cool down. This can allow food poisoning bacteria or toxins to grow in your food.

You can reduce the time it takes to for food to cool by:

  • cooking smaller portions
  • separating batches into smaller, shallow containers.

See the factsheet below for more information on cooling food safety. To show you are cooling food safely, you can choose to keep records like the template record sheet at the end of the topic.

components.legend: When reheating potentially hazardous food, do you make sure food is
components.label: When reheating potentially hazardous food, do you make sure food is
HTML
components.content: • reheated to 60°C or hotter within 2 hours

components.label: When reheating potentially hazardous food, do you make sure food is
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your reheated food may not be safe as it has taken too long to reach a temperature that stops the growth of food poisoning bacteria or toxins.

See the factsheet at the end of the topic for more information on reheating food.

components.legend: Do you thaw or defrost frozen food safely?
components.label: Do you thaw or defrost frozen food safely?
HTML
components.content:
Safe methods include:

  • place the frozen food in the refrigerator
  • place under cold running water
  • defrost in the microwave
  • heat as part of the cooking process.

components.label: Do you thaw or defrost frozen food safely?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

It is also important to make sure the juices from your thawed food do not drip onto other food contaminating it.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food must be thawed safely to limit the growth of food poisoning bacteria and toxins.

It is important to make sure the juices from the thawing food do not drip onto other food contaminating it.

components.legend: Do you use food grade packaging?
components.label: Do you use food grade packaging?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> Containers or wrapping that is suitable to use with food. </small>

components.label: Do you use food grade packaging?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You may be contaminating your food by using materials that are not suitable. Your supplier will be able to advise if the products are ok to use with food if it is not written on the packaging.

components.legend: Do you use single use items more than once?
components.label: Do you use single use items more than once?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • gloves
  • foils, wrappers and packaging
  • ice cream containers and disposable takeaway containers

components.label: Do you use single use items more than once?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Single use items are designed to only be used once. They must be thrown out:

  • after they have been used
  • if they are potentially contaminated.

Single use items cannot be washed or used again.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:

HTML
components.content:
Display and serve food

When you choose to display food at your business, you need to make sure that the food stays safe at all time. This includes food that is:

  • displayed for self-service
  • on a counter bar
  • inside a refrigerator

How you protect food will depend on the way you display it, and the type of food on display.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • What type of food do you display?
  • How do you display food?
  • How do you protect food while it is displayed?
  • What single use items do you have in your food business?
  • How do you display and use the single use items?

components.content:
